links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field
The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien
The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{poem infobox | title=''Ferrum et Sanguis: 1914'' | image= | caption= | imageWidth= | imageHeight= | other names=''1914'',
''Ferrum et Sanguis'' | written=[[22 December]], [[1914]] | revised=[[22 December]], [[1914]] | published=''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[World War I]] }} '''''Ferrum et Sanguis: 1914''''', or simply '''''Ferrum et Sanguis''''',{{CG|Po}}, "By Title", p. 845 (entry "''Ferrum et Sanguis''. Unpublished.") is a poem with a "theme of darkness"{{CG|C}}, p. 59 (entry "27 December 1914") written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] on [[22 December]] of [[1914]].{{CG|C}}, p. 58 (entry "22 December 1914") ==Poem excerpt== :The earth and all that dwell thereon are dark in a great gloom: :A frightful hand has dared its shade across the blackened sun, :And, lest the stars come out and still do light us in its room, :Has fouled the heavens with his touch, or plucked them one by one{{CP|21}}, pp. 120-2 ==Background== On [[22 December]] of [[1914]], probably a day after writing the poem ''[[Dark]]'',{{CG|C}}, p. 58 (entry "21 December 1914") [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote the poem, '''1914''', the earliest draft of ''Ferrum et Sanguis: 1914''. Tolkien inscribed the poem's first manuscript with the [[Latin]] phrases "Ex umbris et loco tenebroso" ("out of the shadows and the dark place") and "De Profundis" ("out of the depths"). Later, Tolkien made a "slightly revised version" in which he separated many of the lines in two and renamed the poem to ''Ferrum et Sanguis'' ("iron and blood") in [[Latin]]. Even later, Tolkien rewrote the poem in pencil on two new manuscripts, naming it ''Ferrum et Sanguis: 1914'' on both and making minor revisions. In [[2014]], Raymond Edwards suggested in his [[Tolkien (2014 book)|biography of Tolkien]] that Tolkien's poem is related "to the political situation of [[World War I]]".{{webcite |author= [https://x.com/tolkienthoughts Thoughts on Tolkien]|articleurl= https://x.com/tolkienthoughts/status/1819232105748160707|articlename= #18
On December 22, 1914, Tolkien wrote a poem called "Ferrum et Sanguis," Latin for "Iron and Blood." Raymond Edwards speculates that the poem relates to the political situation of World War I, and Scull & Hammond describe the poem as having a theme of "darkness."|dated= 1 August 2024|website= X|accessed= 5 January 2026|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}} In [[September]] of [[2024]], the poem was published for the first time as entry 21 in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''. In their commentary, [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] explain that Tolkien's poem, like ''[[Dark]]'', had a "theme of darkness" concerning the [[World War I|Great War]] but, unlike the earlier poem, ''Ferrum et Sanguis: 1914'' reflected the "sinking of spirits which he projected onto the whole of the Earth and even the heavens".{{CP|Introduction}}, p. xix They also explain that the phrase "iron and blood" is "from a speech by the nineteenth-century German leader [[Wikipedia:Otto von Bismarck|Otto von Bismarck]]" referring "to the use of military power to unify Germany and extend its territory" and that the Latin phrase "De Profundis…are the first words of one of the penitential psalms ('Out of the depths I call to you, Lord; Lord, hear my cry!'), a prayer for the dead". Hammond and Scull further suggest that, in using the Latin phrase "ex umbris et loco tenebroso", Tolkien might have been thinking of the "Tenebrae" ("service of shadows"), a service "conducted by the Catholic Church in Holy Week, in which candles are gradually extinguished until the room is in total darkness". In an article in an issue from the ''Journal of Tolkien Research'', Patrick J. Lyon suggested that the poem references the "O Antiphon" for [[21 December]] from "the Catholic Advent Vespers" instead of, "or in addition to"{{webcite |author= [[Christina Scull]] and [[Wayne G. Hammond]]|articleurl= https://www.hammondandscull.com/addenda/collected_poems_by_date.html|articlename= Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien'' (2024) Arranged by Date|dated= 4 September 2024|website= HS|accessed= 5 January 2026|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}}, "'''pp. 120-2:''' Patrick J. Lyon has suggested that Tolkien’s inspiration for ''Ferrum et Sanguis'' lay in the Advent Vespers sung at the time he wrote the poem, particularly the ‘O Antiphon’ for 21 December – ‘O Oriens, splendor lucis aeternae, et sol justitiae: veni, et illumina sedentes in tenebris, et umbra mortis’ (‘O Light of the East, splendour of light eternal, and sun of righteousness: come, and enlighten those who dwell in darkness and the shadow of death’) – rather than, or in addition to, the Tenebrae service we mention as a possibility. Lyon also suggests that the darkness of the poem is related to the Winter Solstice, the shortest day of the year (22 December in 1914), and that Tolkien was more broadly influenced by the Antiphons sung earlier in Vespers, one of which lay behind the Old English ''Crist'' which inspired ''The Voyage of Earendel the Evening Star''.", the "Tenebrae".{{webcite |author= Patrick J. Lyon|articleurl= https://scholar.valpo.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1434&context=journaloftolkienresearch|articlename= Antiphons of Iron and Blood: The Inspirations of Tolkien's Poetry|dated= 2024|website= [https://scholar.valpo.edu/ ValpoScholar] - [https://www.valpo.edu/ Valparaiso University]|accessed= 5 January 2026|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}}, ''[https://scholar.valpo.edu/journaloftolkienresearch/ Journal of Tolkien Research]'': [https://scholar.valpo.edu/journaloftolkienresearch/vol20/ Volume 20], [https://scholar.valpo.edu/journaloftolkienresearch/vol20/iss2/ Issue 2], [https://scholar.valpo.edu/journaloftolkienresearch/vol20/iss2/7?utm_source=scholar.valpo.edu%2Fjournaloftolkienresearch%2Fvol20%2Fiss2%2F7&utm_medium=PDF&utm_campaign=PDFCoverPages Article 7] {{References}} {{Poems}} [[Category:Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien]]
